I have a theory that everyone is everyone else. Like, you have person A and B, and A thinks it's A and not B, and B thinks it's B and not A. But A and B are in the brain of person C (or you can think of it like C is reading the minds of both A and B). So C has the experience of thinking it's A and not B, and thinking it's B and not A, and maybe independent C thoughts not in A or B.
Maybe people are like A and B, but we're all just C. Helps to explain why I feel like me and not like someone else. Any constructive criticism on this theory?

am i allowed to call myself autistic (or say i ~identify with the autism spectrum~ or what fucking ever) based on years spent getting to know autism and myself, and a sense of "holy shit i finally get it now, this diagnosis is actually a rly useful framework for me to understand why i am like how i am" or do i have to wait until i get to the top of a provincial healthcare waitlist and find a doctor who agrees with me? because i'm getting pretty fucking tired of the latter hahahahah aaaaaahhh ah ahanaha haha

any of the traits fount in an autistic diagnosis are well within the range of 'human' style traits and behaviors. they may not be traits that everyone has, but they are still vastly human traits. thousands and hundreds if not zillions of people have those traits. but if you are waiting for a doctor to write you permission to be yourself, i would pose the question: who do you think writes the doctors permission to be themselves? i'll tell you the answer: it's larger doctors. the point of this story is to see if you can locate the largest doctor and see if you can get them to write you permission to become a very large doctor, not the largest but possibly second largest

let's say that i desperately wanna make my own music, just as you are, but i have absolutely no experience in making my voice sound remotely good. i've got good ears and pitch and everything, but the voice just sounds bad and the technique is nonexistent. how do you think i could at least get my voice to a good baseline which i could expand on throughout my life, in like a solid two months?
i know "just do it a lot" is a great answer here, but how do i "just do it" well enough that i can make solid progress along with that? i think i know how this works for physical instruments which i can observe the mechanics of in front of my eyes, but the voice is too obscure, where should i even start? i can feel myself dipping into that 13th level of suffering

this is similar to what i went through, because i am working from the same starting point as you. but you will already be better after 1 month. and at 2 months you will be a little better. and at 3 months you will be better. so the 'baseline' you are working with is actually right now, that's your starting point. 2 months from now will be the middle. unless you stop singing entirely after 2 months. 
for specifics on technique, for some reason no professional vocal technical advice ever made any sense to me until many years later, and much of it still doesn't. i found that the voice is so deeply connected with life itself that it was almost impossible for me to think directly about most of the things professionals tell you to think about. so i had to find much more abstract tricks. one of the most important tricks i learned was to improvise the lyrics. and for scripted material, try to do it like you are terrified of joe jackson whipping you

i had an anagram-related ethical dilemma yesterday and was wondering what you'd have done in my situation so i have more insight next time something similar happens.

i was recertifying my first aid training for the 1939545th time and i was bored out of my skull, so i took a pen and the little manuals they give you and started writing possible anagrams next to the chapter headers. there were lots of wild ones, but i think "bone, joint, and muscle injuries" ---> "boner juice slut, join me and sin" was my favourite.

but then!!!!! at the end of the course!!!! THEY ASK FOR THE MANUALS BACK. nobody told me that would happen and the manuals have always been ours to keep at every other certification i've ever attended. so it's like, do i return this and never train with the first aid company again (i have very distinctive handwriting that matches the handwriting on my registration form), or covertly try to steal the manual? i tried the  latter  but a classmate saw and gave me a dirty look so i ended up returning it and shoving it into the middle of the pile. i still don't know whether that was the correct decision.

my worst fear is that the next person reading that manual won't realize the anagrams are in fact anagrams, and will just think i wrote "boner juice slut, join me and sin" over the chapter title for no reason. anyway what would the best course of action have been? do you have any advice for future similar instances of this? thanks

you should put a bracket around the source text, explain in a slightly different font "re-arrage these letters, to get this" and have arrows pointing accordingly. i think anyone reading that can surely be greatful that you've just shown them a pleasingly good time, high brow at that

I've gotten relatively well with identifying melodies and what not, but get absolutely floored with trying to find chords. What would you suggest for me to get better at identifying chords?

go through about 50 of your favorite songs, and identify them with brute force. quickly unpause/pause (or nowadays you can edit to loop a tiny fraction of audio very quickly) and just pick it out note by note and put it together. write down all the chords to a song (in time, with bar lines, etc.)..... once you do this for about 30 or 40 songs, i think you will find that you don't have to search for the individual notes anymore. ... maybe not even pause it at all. After about 100 more songs, you probably won't even have to listen to the song, you will be able to do it from memory. after about 1000 songs, you will probably be able to hear someone singing the melody for a song you have never heard before, without hearing the chords, and figure out what the chords should be. after 10,000 songs, you should be able to play along with them on the first try, never having heard the song before, and have them think you already knew the song
